October 4, 1992: Fiction
WHERE IS JOE MERCHANT? by Jimmy Buffett. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich,
$19.95.) A couple on a wild chase through the Caribbean on the trail of a
deceased rock star who has been sighted there.
THE PELICAN BRIEF, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $22.50.) A woman law
student probes the murder of two Supreme Court justices.
WAITING TO EXHALE, by Terry McMillan. (Viking, $22.) The friendships and
romances of four black women in Phoenix.
GERALD'S GAME, by Stephen King. (Viking, $23.50.) Twenty-eight hours of
horror suffered by a woman handcuffed to a bedpost.
THE SECRET HISTORY, by Donna Tartt. (Knopf, $23.) Close friends at a small
college must deal with the consequences of a crime they committed.
THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY, by Robert James Waller. (Warner,
$14.95.) A photographer and a lonely farmer's wife in Iowa.
ALL THAT REMAINS, by Patricia D. Cornwell. (Scribners, $20.) Searching for the
truth behind the strange deaths of five young couples in Virginia.
THE VOLCANO LOVER, by Susan Sontag. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) The
story of Lord Nelson, his lover Emma Hamilton and her spouse.
TANGLED VINES, by Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) Visiting her native
Napa Valley, a television star encounters shades of her unhappy childhood and
romance with the heir to a winery.
THE LEGACY, by R. A. Salvatore. (TSR, $15.95.) A fantasy tale about a spider
queen's war to stop a band of elves in their quest for peace and security.
THE CAT WHO WASN'T THERE, by Lilian Jackson Braun. (Putnam, $18.95.) Jim
Qwilleran has to contend with a series of crimes that occur during a bus tour of
Scotland.
BEFORE AND AFTER, by Rosellen Brown. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $21.) A
tragic event in a New England town pits members of a family against one another.
SWEET LIAR, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $22.) In New York, a Kentucky woman
copes with a mystery dating back to the Roaring Twenties.
LIVE FROM GOLGOTHA, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $22.) The Gospel
according to St. Timothy, recorded in A.D. 96 amid intrusions by 20th-century
religious and media personalities.
COLONY, by Anne Rivers Siddons. (HarperCollins, $20.) A 90-year-old woman
October 4, 1992
Non-Fiction
THE WAY THINGS OUGHT TO BE, by Rush H. Limbaugh 3d. (Pocket, $22.)
Anecdotes and opinions offered by the radio talk show host.
EVERY LIVING THING, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) Continuing the
memoirs of the Yorkshire veterinarian.
THE SILENT PASSAGE, by Gail Sheehy. (Random House, $16.) The
psychological and social significance of menopause for today's women.
TRUMAN, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) A biography of the 33d
President.
EARTH IN THE BALANCE, by Al Gore. (Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) The Vice-
Presidential candidate discusses factors affecting the environment and what must
be done to save it.
THE TE OF PIGLET, by Benjamin Hoff. (Dutton, $16.) Aspects of Taoist
philosophy explained through the actions of A. A. Milne's character Piglet.
DIANA: HER TRUE STORY, by Andrew Morton. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) A
biography of the Princess of Wales.
WOMEN WHO RUN WITH THE WOLVES, by Clarissa Pinkola Estes. (Ballantine,
$20.) A Jungian analyst reinterprets myths and folk tales to enable women to
understand their psyches.
THE LAST TSAR, by Edvard Radzinsky. (Doubleday, $25.) The life of Nicholas II
and his family, and their assassination in 1918; based in part on newly available
material.
YOUNG MEN & FIRE, by Norman Maclean. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) An
account of a disastrous fire in a Montana forest in 1949.
UP IN THE OLD HOTEL, by Joseph Mitchell. (Pantheon, $27.50.) Three dozen
pieces about Manhattan life, published in The New Yorker during the past half-
century.
CARE OF THE SOUL, by Thomas Moore. (HarperCollins, $20.) A
psychotherapist's discussion of spirituality and everyday life.
HEAD TO HEAD, by Lester Thurow. (Morrow, $25.) The upcoming economic
battle among Japan, Europe and the United States.
WHO WILL TELL THE PEOPLE, by William Greider. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A
journalist's account of how powerful monied interests and elite groups dominate
the Federal Government.
